item.title: Henri Bergius
item.description:
Henri Bergius

Hacker and an occasional adventurer. Author of Create.js and NoFlo. Decoupling software, one piece at a time.

item.title: Artificial intelligence: 'Homo sapiens will be split into a handful of gods and the rest of us'
item.description:
Artificial intelligence: 'Homo sapiens will be split into a handful of gods and the rest of us'

If you wanted relief from stories about tyre factories and steel plants closing, you could try relaxing with a new 300-page report from Bank of America Merrill Lynch which looks at the likely effects of a robot revolution. But you might not end up reassured.

item.title: Finland's new national emoji include a heavy metal guy and a Nokia 3310
item.description:
Finland's new national emoji include a heavy metal guy and a Nokia 3310

Finland, that northern European haven of moose, death metal, and milk, has just become the first country to create a set of national emoji. More than 30 Finland-specific emoji will be available to download on the web worldwide on December 30th, The Guardian reports.

item.title: Living Lightly with the One-Bag Lifestyle
item.description:
Living Lightly with the One-Bag Lifestyle

I've been on a handful of long trips this year and in recent years, and on all those trips, I lived out of a small bag. I loved living so lightly, but every time I came home, it felt weird: all of a sudden I had about 10x more stuff.

item.title: The /now page movement
item.description:
The /now page movement

People often ask me what I’m doing now. Each time I would type out a reply, describing where I’m at, what I’m focused on, and what I’m not. So earlier this year I added a /now page to my site: sivers.org/now

item.title: A 101 Noob Intro to Programming Smart Contracts on Ethereum
item.description:
A 101 Noob Intro to Programming Smart Contracts on Ethereum

Some people say Ethereum is too logic-heavy and hard to use, but here’s a write-up to give you a feel for building smart contracts and applications with it. Tools, wallets, applications and the ecosystem are still in development and it’ll get easier!

item.title: The first great works of digital literature are already being written
item.description:
The first great works of digital literature are already being written

It's an unfortunate feature of working as both a novelist and a games designer that I end up sitting through a lot of panels, round-tables, conferences, discussions and other exercises in head-nodding where digital people try to get to grips with storytelling, or where story people try to understand the digital world.

item.title: Programmable blockchains in context: Ethereum's Future
item.description:
Programmable blockchains in context: Ethereum's Future

By the end of this article, you're going to understand blockchains in general (and Ethereum, a next-generation blockchain platform, in particular) well enough to decide what they mean to your life. Ethereum brings up strong emotions. Some have compared it to SkyNet, the distributed artificial intelligence of the Terminator movies.

item.title: A Declaration of the Independence of Cyberspace
item.description:
A Declaration of the Independence of Cyberspace

Governments of the Industrial World, you weary giants of flesh and steel, I come from Cyberspace, the new home of Mind. On behalf of the future, I ask you of the past to leave us alone. You are not welcome among us. You have no sovereignty where we gather.

item.title: Google's AMP-an Internet giant tackles the old myth of "the Web is too slow"
item.description:
Google's AMP-an Internet giant tackles the old myth of "the Web is too slow"

There's a story going around today that the Web is too slow, especially over mobile networks. It's a pretty good story-and it's a perpetual story. The Web, while certainly improved from the days of 14.4k modems, has never been as fast as we want it to be, which is to say that the Web has never been instantaneous.
